q: 1. What is the main difference between cyclical and linear annealing in terms of pattern diversity?
options: A) Cyclical annealing maintains higher pattern diversity than linear annealing does. [Ans: A]
B) Linear annealing maintains higher pattern diversity due to its monotonic increase. [C]
C) Both cyclical and linear annealing provide equal levels of pattern diversity. [D]

q: 2. Which aspect is often a downside of using linear annealing?
options: A) It leads to premature collapse, causing repetitive patterns in the output. [Ans: A]
B) Cyclical annealing takes too long for practical use due to its non-monotonic nature. [C]
C) Linear annealing maintains a consistent pattern without any diversity throughout. [D]

q: 3. How does cyclical annealing differ from linear annealing in terms of the KL constraint?
options: A) Cyclical annealing gives periodic breaks, sustaining both musically coherent outputs and diversity. [Ans: A]
B) Linear annealing has no impact on pattern repetition or breaking constraints with time progression. [C]
C) Both cyclical and linear methods of annealing completely remove the KL constraint during processing. [D]
